edge: In August 1968, the Democratic National Convention was held in Chicago.
In August 1968, Abbie Hoffman and Jerry Rubin made preparations to protest at the Democratic National Convention in Chicago.
In August 1968, Tom Hayden and Rennie Davis made preparations to protest at the Democratic National Convention in Chicago.
Abbie Hoffman openly antagonized Judge Julius Hoffman during the trial.
During the trial, Fred Hampton showed support for Seale, which Judge Julius Hoffman assumed was legal help.
Judge Julius Hoffman showed significant prejudice for the prosecution and insisted that he and Abbie Hoffman are not related.

Judge Julius Hoffman removed two jurors who he suspected sympathized with the defendants due to alleged threats from the Black Panther Party and charged the defendants and their attorneys with multiple counts of contempt of court.
Numerous undercover police officers and FBI agents testified during the trial.

During the riot, Davis attempted to pacify the police officers trying to arrest someone climbing a flagpole. After the police clubbed Davis's head, Hayden exclaimed 'If blood is going to flow, then let it flow all over the city!'
At the time of the convention, Hayden noticed two police officers tailing Davis and attempted to let the air out of their tire. He was caught and later arrested.

During the riot, police had taken control of the hill with orders to disperse the crowd leading to a riot between police and protesters. When trying to return to the park, Hayden was detained after being caught by police.
In retaliation for Seale continuing to speak up for his constitutional rights, Judge Hoffman had him taken to another room, beaten, and returned gagged and chained.

The defense put Ramsey Clark, Attorney General during the riots, on the stand. Judge Hoffman refused to let him testify in front of the jury as he had declined to initiate prosecutions after the riots because of evidence that the Chicago Police Department instigated them.
During the trial, Dellinger punched a bailiff, resulting in his arrest.
